text: Temperature - induced down-regulation of the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in peripheral blood mononuclear leucocyte in patients with sepsis or septic shock .
OBJECTIVE : Activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis is of vital importance during critical illness .

We have studied the adaptive mechanisms which occur at the level of the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in glucocorticoid target tissues in patients with sepsis or septic shock .

DESIGN : The effects of hypercortisolaemia , hyperthermia and cellular composition on number of <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> per cell and their affinity were evaluated , both in vitro and in vivo , in peripheral blood mononuclear leucocytes of control subjects and in patients with sepsis or septic shock .
SUBJECTS : Fifteen patients ( age 25-79 ) with sepsis or septic shock who were admitted to an intensive care unit were studied .
The control group consisted of 24 healthy laboratory employees .

MEASUREMENTS : The binding capacity and affinity of the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were measured and compared to clinical data and the plasma cortisol concentrations .
RESULTS : Hypercortisolaemia , in vitro , resulted in a decreased affinity and a decreased binding capacity of the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
In vitro , hyperthermia as well as variations in the cellular composition did not influence the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
In vivo , there was no change in the number of receptors per cell in patients with sepsis or septic shock as compared to healthy controls .
However , a decreased affinity of the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was observed .
There was a weak but significant negative correlation between body temperature and the number of <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the patient group .
There was no relation between circulating cortisol concentrations and <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> affinity and number .
CONCLUSIONS : There is no obvious regulation of the number of <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by plasma cortisol concentrations in vivo .

The decreased affinity of the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> together with the negative correlation between hyperthermia and the number of <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptors <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in patients with sepsis or septic shock suggest that hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis activation during critical illness is accompanied by peripheral adaptation in <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> number and affinity .
